I have not needed to use suite() much since moving to Eclipse 3.0 (other th=
an when I was using Eclipse 3.1.2 just before Eclipse 3.2 and I started usi=
ng JUnit 4, so all of my classes have suite methods for backwards compatibi=
lity with the Runner and ant). When you mentioned the suite thing, it seeme=
d intuitive. I'd say keep it as it. It certainly makes sense in both situat=
ions and it's clear.
 
As for @BeforeSuite/@AfterSuite being more intuitive=
, I don't agree. It's more to remember.
 
If a class has a suite method, @B=
eforeClass happens before that, right? If a class just has a bunch of @Test=
, then it runs before all of them. What is not intuitive about that?
 
And =
if you have both, then what would happen if you had both @BeforeClass and @=
BeforeSuite? I guess @BeforeSuite would happen before @BeforeClass? But tha=
t doesn't seem to make sense since Class is a bigger "container" of stuff t=
han "suite" so now we get unexpected or hard to justify results.
 
No, I th=
ink one set of annotations is wholly adequate, intuitive and simple.
 
Bret=
t

From: David Saff <saff@...>

com
Sent: Friday, August 11, 2006 1:25:21 PM
Subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4 w=
ith bea 9.2 workshop

C=C3=A9dric Beust =E2=99=94 wrote:
> On 8/11/06, Davi=
d Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
> There are indeed several ways to achieve t=
his with JUnit, but why not simply
> add @BeforeSuite and @AfterSuite? The =
intent would be much clearer,
> wouldn't it?
> 

Maybe. What do people thin=
k? For me, @BeforeClass and @AfterClass 
already mean "before everything co=
ming from _this_ class", and "after 
everything coming from _this_ class", =
whether that's all the methods on 
a test class, or all the classes referen=
ced from a Suite class. This 
means that @BeforeClass has a consistent mean=
ing on both suite classes 
and test classes. If suite classes have BeforeSu=
ite, and test classes 
have BeforeClass, then what does BeforeClass mean on=
 a suite class? What 
does BeforeSuite mean on a test class? It seems that =
fewer concepts is 
better.

Thoughts from frequent JUnit users?

David
